dashboard.description:
# User and device compliance
Mac OS and mobile device analytics are now a part of the Nexthink end-user IT analytics platform. With this content pack, you can now seamlessly discover and analyze data coming from any device that connects to your IT infrastructure:
* Windows * Mac OS * Mobile
Furthermore, you can define and monitor in real-time your compliance criteria across any device. A dedicated section allows you to validate compliance of mobile users.
# Active devices
This dashboard helps you to gain visibility over your IT infrastructure in terms of operating systems, hardware and platforms (Windows, Mac OS and mobile devices). You can follow its evolution over time.
::: configuration
You might want to verify the following categorization of your infrastructure:
* [device - hardware type](nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=Hardware%20type&Type=device) * [device - OS name](nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=OS%20name&Type=device) :::
dashboard.name: Active devices

dashboard.description:
# BYOD
Devices can be corporately owned or employees can bring their own devices. This dashboard can help you to follow the trends and adoptions of such policies in your organization.
::: configuration
The category [device - ownership](nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=Ownership&Type=device) is used to classify whether a device is “Corporate” or “BYOD”. :::
::: tip There are a couple of options to tag the devices:
* Manual tagging * Auto-tagging rules based on the fields: “device name”, “distinguished name”, “group name” or “membership type” * When deploying the collector on BYOD devices, use the optional parameter * “DRV_TAG” in the MSI installer. You can then create an auto-tagging rule based on the field “Collector tag”. [More information](http://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/latest/InstallationAndConfiguration/CollectorMSIparametersreferencetable#Optional_parameters).
* Use NXQL to tag the devices based on an external source of data (CMDB or similar). [More documentation](http://doc.nexthink.com/Documentation/Nexthink/latest/APIAndIntegrations/NXQLTutorial#Updating_values_of_categories_and_custom_fields). :::
dashboard.name: BYOD

titleConfig.title: Device users (some may be both BYOD and Corporate device users)

dashboard.description:
# Device compliance
The dashboard displays a set of key device compliance metrics that can be configured to match the corporate policy.
::: configuration
**Non-standard OS** * Running a non-standard OS can result in security vulnerabilities and various issues as IT services are usually tested on a limited set of operating systems. Configuration with the category [device - OS compliance](nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=OS%20compliance&Type=device).
**Non-corporate browser** * Running a non-corporate browser can result in security vulnerabilities and various issues as IT services are usually tested on a limited set of browsers. Configuration with the category [binary - compliance](nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=Compliance&Type=binary).
**Unsupported versions of Adobe Reader / Java** * Old versions of these executables are often subject to security vulnerabilities and incompatibilities. Configuration with the category [binary - support policy](nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=Support%20policy&Type=binary).
**Forbidden applications** * Certain applications should be forbidden for security, policy or regulatory reasons. Examples include Dropbox and torrenting clients. Configuration with the category [binary - compliance](nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=Compliance&Type=binary).
**Devices without corporate antivirus** * Devices without a corporate antivirus represent a security risk. Configuration with the category [package - compliance](nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=Compliance&Type=package).
**Antivirus / Antispyware / Firewall issues** * Even if a device has the corporate security solution installed, it is important to verify that this product is working correctly
**OS not updated for at least 30 days** * Devices not updated in a long time represent a security risk. You can modify the [metric](nxt://Edit-NxMetric?Encoding=Url&Name=Windows%20devices%20with%20OS%20not%20updated%20for%20at%20least%2030%20days).
**Devices not rebooted for at least 30 days** * Windows update and security patches often require a device reboot to become effective. You can modify the metric for [Windows](nxt://Edit-NxMetric?Encoding=Url&Name=Windows%20devices%20not%20rebooted%20for%20at%20least%2030%20days) and for [Mac OS](nxt://Edit-NxMetric?Encoding=Url&Name=Mac%20devices%20with%20not%20rebooted%20for%20at%20least%2030%20days).
**Windows license not activated** * Non-activated Windows licenses can imply regulatory issues.
**Mobile policies** * **Policy not fully applied or enforced**: Mobile devices allowed to connect but where the security policy is not necessarily completely applied. * **Policy not enforced**: Mobile devices allowed to connect but where the security policy is not enforced. * **Personal exemption**: Mobile devices allowed to connect because of an exemption to a particular user. Depending on the policy, this might indicate an abuse. * **No encryption required**: If one or more of these policies are not required or applied and the device is lost or stolen, then corporate data might leak. * **Email attachment enabled**: sensitive information could be downloaded on the mobile. * **No SD card encryption required**: If one or more of these policies are not required or applied and the device is lost or stolen, then corporate data might leak. :::
dashboard.name: Device compliance

metric.label: OS not updated for at least 30 days
Not rebooted for at least 30 days
Not rebooted for at least 30 days
Policy not fully applied or enforced

dashboard.description:
# Mobile user compliance
This dashboard displays a set of key device compliance metrics related to mobile users that can be configured to match the corporate policy.
# User access
This section focuses on what can be used and accessed by users.
**Users with more than 2 mobile devices** * In general users have one or two mobile devices (for instance a phone and a tablet). If a user has more than two, this might indicate a lost or sold device that still has corporate access. Additionally the more mobile devices a user has, the higher are the associated risks such as obsolete OS or unauthorized access to the device. You can configure the [metric](nxt://Edit-NxMetric?Encoding=Url&Name=Users%20with%20more%20than%202%20mobile%20devices) to fine tune the number of allowed mobiles.
**Users with more than 1 laptop** * In general users have at most one laptop. If a user has more than one, this might indicate a lost or sold device that still has corporate access. You can configure the [metric](nxt://Edit-NxMetric?Encoding=Url&Name=Users%20with%20more%20than%201%20laptop) to fine tune the number of allowed laptops.
**Local users with administrator privileges** * Most users should not be allowed to login with a local user account with administrator privileges. You can configure the category [user - account type](nxt://Edit-NxCategory?Encoding=Url&Name=Account%20type&Type=user) to include or exclude special accounts.
# Mobile usage The mobile usage section shows the evolution of users with mobile devices in three possible states: allowed, quarantined, blocked. The evolution should be tracked to validate that mobile device adoption matches the corporate policy.
dashboard.name: Mobile user compliance

metric.label: Users with more than 2 mobile devices
Users with more than 2 mobile devices
